metadata.title: Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization Embedded with Metadata Influence
metadata.author: Trong Dinh Thac Do, Longbing Cao
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: A conjugate Gamma-Poisson model for Dynamic Matrix Factorization incorporated with metadata influence (mGDMF for short) is proposed to effectively and efficiently model massive, sparse and dynamic data in recommendations. Modeling recommendation problems with a massive number of ratings and very sparse or even no ratings on some users/items in a dynamic setting is very demanding and poses critical challenges to well-studied matrix factorization models due to the large-scale, sparse and dynamic nature of the data. Our proposed mGDMF tackles these challenges by introducing three strategies: (1) constructing a stable GammaMarkov chain model that smoothly drifts over time by combining both static and dynamic latent features of data; (2) incorporating the user/item metadata into the model to tackle sparse ratings; and (3) undertaking stochastic variational inference to efficiently handle massive data. mGDMF is conjugate, dynamic and scalable. Experiments show that mGDMF significantly (both effectively and efficiently) outperforms the state-of-the-art static and dynamic models on large, sparse and dynamic data.

highlights: An increasing amount of research [8, 21, 13, 25, 3, 16, 34] focuses on the significant real-life recommendation challenges of modeling massive and evolving ratings (e.g., a girl likes cartoon movies in her childhood but this may change to romantic movies when she is older) but some users have only a few or or even no ratings

Dynamic and massive ratings, we propose a Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization model incorporated with metadata influence. mGDMF has three builtin mechanisms to jointly address user/item rating sparsity, large-scale ratings, and rating dynamics

We report 10 users with the most precisely recommended items and the percentage of precisely recommended sparse items in the top-100 recommendations to compare mGDMF and Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization with dynamic compound PF on LFM-Tracks which has the most dynamic and richest metadata

The sparse item is calculated as the fraction of the non-missing ratings for that in the total number of users. For those items with < 6% ratings, Figure 2 shows that mGDMF recommends more than dynamic compound PF of these sparse items to the 10 users. For those items with sparsity < 1%, mGDMF recommends on average 1.6% items per user compared to 0.2% by dynamic compound PF, attributed to the richer priors and the mGDMF models with metadata integration and aggregating static and dynamic portions

We proposed a novel dynamic Poisson Factorization model: Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization with Metadata Influence to effectively and efficiently model three major challenges in real-life massive recommendations: massive data with sparse and evolving ratings. mGDMF significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art static and dynamic models on five large datasets. mGDMF can further tackle massive, sparse and evolving data by involving time-dependent metadata for scalable recommendation and tackling challenges in other applications such as context-aware chatbot by involving textual and sequential information

Dynamic and massive ratings, we propose a Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization model incorporated with metadata influence. mGDMF has three builtin mechanisms to jointly address user/item rating sparsity, large-scale ratings, and rating dynamics

We report 10 users with the most precisely recommended items and the percentage of precisely recommended sparse items in the top-100 recommendations to compare mGDMF and Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization with dynamic compound PF on LFM-Tracks which has the most dynamic and richest metadata

For those items with sparsity < 1%, mGDMF recommends on average 1.6% items per user compared to 0.2% by dynamic compound PF, attributed to the richer priors and the mGDMF models with metadata integration and aggregating static and dynamic portions

summary: An increasing amount of research [8, 21, 13, 25, 3, 16, 34] focuses on the significant real-life recommendation challenges of modeling massive and evolving ratings (e.g., a girl likes cartoon movies in her childhood but this may change to romantic movies when she is older) but some users have only a few or or even no ratings.
MGDMF is the only PF model that incorporates user/item metadata, embedded with more general attributes to work with dynamic data.
The user/item metadata is modeled as Gamma priors of the latent user preference/latent item attractiveness in the static portion.ii/1.(b).ii in the mGDMF generative process).

We assume the rating matrix Yt at time slice t follows the Poisson distribution and can be factorized to vectors representing K latent user preferences and vectors representing K latent item attractiveness.
The static portions capture the global stationary factors for user u and item i, which are not influenced by time, and are assumed to follow the Gamma distribution.
MGDMF effectively models both static and dynamic characteristics of user preference and item attractiveness in the context of having sparse ratings on users/items.
MGDMF integrates both observable user/item metadata and latent static/dynamic portions.
We adopt stochastic optimization by sampling a data point from the rating yui,t of user u on item i to update its local parameters as in batch inference, and update the global variables.
MGDMF is evaluated in terms of its capability to model dynamic data and data with sparse user/item ratings and its efficiency in handling large data.
The mGDMF without metadata integration is a Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization (GDMF) model to test the effect of metadata integration.

GDMF replaces the rate of Gamma distribution of latent user preference ξu by hyper-parameter a and the item’s latent attractiveness ηi by hyper-parameter c instead of the product of the user/item attribute’s weights.

Figure 1 reports the results w.r.t. Precision@50 and Recall@50 of mGDMF together with GDMF without metadata integration, compared to DCPF, dPF and four static models: HCPF-all, HCPF-last, HPF-all and HPF-last.

We report 10 users with the most precisely recommended items and the percentage of precisely recommended sparse items in the top-100 recommendations to compare mGDMF and GDMF with DCPF on LFM-Tracks which has the most dynamic and richest metadata.

For those items with sparsity < 1%, mGDMF recommends on average 1.6% items per user compared to 0.2% by DCPF, attributed to the richer priors and the mGDMF models with metadata integration and aggregating static and dynamic portions.

We proposed a novel dynamic PF model: Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization with Metadata Influence to effectively and efficiently model three major challenges in real-life massive recommendations: massive data with sparse and evolving ratings.

We proposed a novel dynamic PF model: Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization with Metadata Influence to effectively and efficiently model three major challenges in real-life massive recommendations: massive data with sparse and evolving ratings. mGDMF significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art static and dynamic models on five large datasets. mGDMF can further tackle massive, sparse and evolving data by involving time-dependent metadata for scalable recommendation and tackling challenges in other applications such as context-aware chatbot by involving textual and sequential information
headline: Dynamic and massive ratings, we propose a Gamma-Poisson Dynamic Matrix Factorization model incorporated with metadata influence . mGDMF has three builtin mechanisms to jointly address user/item rating sparsity, large-scale ratings, and rating dynamics
